author: MIROSHA GENESAN
title: Celebrating love in their twilight years
text:
by mirosha genesan Toh (standing left) presenting ang pow to the guests, who were also given signature sugar-friendly cookies to take home. 
DORSETT Kuala Lumpur treated 12 underprivileged elderly from Sri Jayanti Metta Care Centre to a Valentine’s Day buffet luncheon. 
The annual charity event was part of Dorsett Kuala Lumpur’s corporate social responsibility (CSR) programme in giving back to the community and the less fortunate. 
The underprivileged elderly, aged between 65 and 88 years old, were accompanied by volunteer workers from the home as well as the home caretaker KL Tan. 
One of the elderly guests with his cupcake. 
“I was very happy when we were asked to join this celebration as it gives the elderly a new experience and they are able to be loved once again,” said Tan. 
Dorsett Kuala Lumpur area general manager Christina Toh welcomed the elderly from the home at the hotel’s newly-renovated Checkers Cafe together with her management. 
The event started with a specially prepared buffet, followed by a special performance by Dorsett Kuala Lumpur’s chef Badrol Hisham. 
“I have been in this home for the past seven years and this is the first time I have experienced Valentine’s Day since my husband passed away. 
The guests from Sri Jayanti Metta Care old folks home and hotel staff dancing around Checkers Cafe during the special Valentines Day CSR lunch event. — Photos: NORAFIFI EHSAN/The Star 
“I feel so happy to be here,” said Elsie Tang, 81. 
The hotel also prepared a cupcake decoration activity to further enhance the interaction. 
“It is really fun to recall memories of my younger days,” said Wong Hon Mun, 80. 
’s main objective was to remember the less fortunate elderly not only during festivals but also on Valentine’s Day.
